author: sky.cactus
content:
My calculus here is this:
1. The only benefit this change provides is to make it easier for people to pool.
2. We do not want people to pool.
3. This change requires non-zero work.
Conclusion: We are doing non-zero work to make it easier for people to do a thing that we don't want people to do.

author: sky.cactus
content: Even if we assert that the reduction in pooling is epsilon, or that the security problems with pooling are epsilon, that is still a bad trade.

author: sky.cactus
content: You can put epsilon in for any/every variable in this calculus and still come out with "this is not a good change".

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree, but in this case users want something that runs contrary to network health.  Users *want* to just delegate validation to a third party, which is something that isn't good for security.  We want as many independent validators as possible to protect against censorship.

author: sky.cactus
content: We certainly could build a system where that is easy (delegated proof of stake).  We have chosen not to because we care about censorship resistance.

author: jgm
content:
On the "every validator should run an execution client" thing: this is dangerously simplistic.  I can go for "we should maximize the number of execution clients", as that is a far more realistic goal.

To be clear: an execution client is a very heavyweight piece of code.  It takes up a lot of CPU, memory, network and disk resource.  As it is, many consensus clients use a centralized service because the requirements are too large for their home setups to handle.

Running anywhere near a 1:1 ratio for execution clients to validators is unrealistic for everyone.  We can argue as to _why_, but the reality of it is clear.  If coinbase was not available in the spec version of the API it would result in there having to be a non-compliant fork (no doubt only of geth and one or two of the "big three" consensus clients, reducing decentralization of choice and increasing operational risk).  It would  result in overall fewer public instances of execution clients, as fewer people would want to run and keep up-to-date with forked software.  It may well end up with a paid-for service, where ultimately most people go through the same gateway to fetch their execution blocks, reducing the number further.

Given that the choice for each staker, with whatever way they have decided to stake to date, is either to run an execution client or not the aim should be to find the ways to maximize the number of execution clients.  This is done by increasing the benefits compared to the costs.  The simple fact that there are a large number of stakers that run execution clients should be applauded, given that to date the benefits are near-0 and the costs a very significant part of the overall infrastructure.  Increasing costs, especially in such an obnoxious way as to cripple the functionality of a node for a purist view of how the world should be and contrary to everything that has been built to date, would be a most regrettable step.

author: sky.cactus
content: Do you believe that a validator who doesn't run an execution client increasing security of the network at all?  Or are they equivalent (from a security standpoint) to having one less validator?

author: sky.cactus
content: I am of the opinion that if you run a consensus client and outsource your execution client then you aren't helping secure the network any more than someone who simply didn't run anything.

author: sky.cactus
content: Perhaps this is the root of our disagreement?  Is there value in terms of network security for having these non-execution-operating validators at all?

author: sky.cactus
content: I could even see an argument that such people are *weakening* the security of the network because they are actively contributing to execution client centralization by giving centralized execution client operators even more staking power.

author: jgm
content:
I think if the overall ratio of execution client to validator client is non-zero then it (probably) improves the security of the network.  If the ratio increases the security increases, if the ratio decreases the security decreases.

And I believe that attempting to force 1:1 will result in the ratio decreasing.

author: sky.cactus
content: Why would forcing 1:1 *decrease* the ratio?

author: sky.cactus
content:
If someone has to make a choice between:
1. Do not run a consensus client.
2. Run a consensus client and not an execution client.
Then (1) will result in the ratio remaining stable, (2) will result in the ratio decreasing (more consensus clients, not more execution clients).

author: sky.cactus
content: So in a situation where someone *cannot* or *will not* run an execution client, I think we *want* them to choose (1) over (2).

author: jgm
content: This is going somewhat off-topic from the original point.  But to be clear: I said _attempting_ to force 1:1 will result in the ratio decreasing.  Because there is an option 3), which is "run a consensus client and let someone else run the execution client", and that is the one that will be increasingly chosen as the burden of running your own execution client  increases.

author: djrtwo
content:
I think their's an abuse of terms causing confusion here

A proof-of-custody on the execution layer would mix in a secret (e.g. privatekey) with the execution that can be trustlessly verified becoming a validity rule on the entire thing (eithr validity rule or later fraud proof on a reveal of a secret). This does not require a 1:1 relationship between *validators* and execution engines, but requires a validator to mix in a secret with whatever execution engine they run -- leading more naturally to a 1:1 ratio on **validator_client** and execution engine

The security model is similar to proof-of-custody for data. Either you did your own execution of that layer or you had to outsource a secret to a third party that could get your slashed

author: djrtwo
content: For something heavy like execution or data availability, there is distinctly a tragedy of the commons issue where it makes more sense to just follow the leader on voting on what the majority sees as correct

author: djrtwo
content: thus the integration of crypto ecnomic methods that proof you either did the work yourself or took on counter party risk to get slashed

author: jgm
content:
A balanced relationship between validator client and execution client makes more sense, although predicating a 1:1 relationship does make it a lot harder to build resilient infrastructure in a sane way (eg a pool of execution clients available to a set of execution clients on a per-request basis).

But even in a world where we have a simple 1:1 validator client and execution client it will be a requirement to be able to have different coinbases for the validators of each validator client.

author: potuz
content: Running at home helps decentralize the network, regardless of how many you run. The point is that if you're not allowed to hide the fact that you run many, then those validators that would otherwise help the network may choose to not do it

author: potuz
content: And also notice that there's actually an impact on decentralization on how many you run. A simple thought exercise is this: if the whole network is 200K  validators and are held by one person. It's 100% centralized. If 1 of those validators are run by someone else it's still 100% centralized. If 100K on the other hand are run by a different person then it's only 50% "centralized"
